Protests have swept the country for nearly two weeks since the Memorial Day death of George Floyd, a black man killed while in Minneapolis police custody. Demonstrations didn't start in Ashland until Thursday, when Singleton, an Ashland...
text:
ASHLAND -- Passing cars honked in support. More than 30 demonstrators of all
ages held their homemade signs high.

Keon Singleton, the protest organizer, spoke through a megaphone to drivers
stopped at Main Street and Claremont Avenue.

A large contingent supporting Black Lives Matter continued to make themselves
seen and heard downtown on Monday for the fourth straight day. Participants
said their numbers pushed 100 over the weekend.

Singleton plans for peaceful protests to continue from 1 to 3 p.m. daily until
there is a "revolution" in this country and black Americans are treated the
same as white Americans.

He refused to talk to a reporter about his efforts, and he discouraged other
protesters Monday from speaking unless the reporter held a sign and took part
in the rally.

Protests have swept the country for nearly two weeks since the Memorial Day
death of George Floyd, a black man killed while in Minneapolis police custody.
Demonstrations didn't start in Ashland until Thursday, when Singleton, an
Ashland University student, marched on Main Street downtown with a handmade
sign. On Friday, the movement kicked off in earnest with more than 50
individuals joining him.

The community has been mostly supportive, said Rebecca Shaw, an Ashland woman
who attended demonstrations Saturday through Monday her 3-year-old and 5-year-
old children and her girlfriend. A few passersby over the weekend yelled
things like "all lives matter" and "Trump 2020," Shaw said.

Ashland City Police Officer Kara Pearce joined the demonstration on Sunday and
held a "Black Lives Matter" sign. Pearce did not return a phone message or
email seeking comment Monday.

"We are proud and thankful that our local community has chosen to demonstrate
peacefully," said Ashland City Police Chief David Marcelli in an emailed
statement.

"Members of the Division are free to participate in demonstrations or not
participate as they choose," he said, noting, "I have received a number of
positive comments concerning Pearce's appearance at the demonstration."

Mark Gorsuch, a Mapleton High School and Ashland University graduate, said on
his first day protesting Monday that he plans to come back every day this
week.

"Ashland is considered sometimes a backward town where civil rights aren't
really emphasized, and I want to show that our community is one that values
civil rights, too," he said.

According to the 2010 U.S. Census, less than 2% of the city of Ashland's
approximately 20,000 residents and fewer than 1% of Ashland County's roughly
50,000 residents are black. When asked about the number of minority officers
on city police staff, Marcelli said the department does not ask applicants
about "race, creed, national origin, or religion."

"We currently have three female officers, the most at any time in our
history," he noted.

Coming together

Protester Alexis Thomas acknowledged that racism exists in small towns like
Ashland, where people "need to come together."

An Ashland native attending Kent State University, Thomas held a sign that
read "racism is a pandemic too," when she attended demonstrations on Saturday
and Monday. She said she wants to participate whenever she can.

While loud protests will continue, a group of local young adults is planning a
vigil for victims of police brutality to be held at 7 p.m. Tuesday at
Brookside West Park.

Hannah Caram, an Ashland native and University of Findlay student who is among
the organizers, said the event is not a demonstration against any police
officers or the Ashland City Police Department. The event's Facebook page
notes, "we welcome any officers who wish to bow their heads with us."

"This event is to support black voices, and it is our responsibility to
listen, learn, and use our privilege to lift up black communities, especially
within Ashland," Caram said. The vigil will honor "the lives that we've lost
and will shed light on them. People will say their names and be more educated
about their stories."

At the vigil, Rev. Wilson Arimi will lead participants in prayer and Columbus-
based political activist Latyna M. Humphrey will speak about unity. Attendees
are encouraged to social distance, wear masks and bring water.

Reach Jordan at 419-281-0581 ext. 240 or [jlaird@times-
gazette.com](mailto:jlaird@times-gazette.com). On Twitter: @JordanSLaird1

title: Ashland protests take aim at racial divide
html:
ASHLAND — Passing cars honked in support. More than 30 demonstrators of all ages held their homemade signs high.

Keon Singleton, the protest organizer, spoke through a megaphone to drivers stopped at Main Street and Claremont Avenue.

A large contingent supporting Black Lives Matter continued to make themselves seen and heard downtown on Monday for the fourth straight day. Participants said their numbers pushed 100 over the weekend.

Singleton plans for peaceful protests to continue from 1 to 3 p.m. daily until there is a "revolution" in this country and black Americans are treated the same as white Americans.

He refused to talk to a reporter about his efforts, and he discouraged other protesters Monday from speaking unless the reporter held a sign and took part in the rally.

Protests have swept the country for nearly two weeks since the Memorial Day death of George Floyd, a black man killed while in Minneapolis police custody. Demonstrations didn't start in Ashland until Thursday, when Singleton, an Ashland University student, marched on Main Street downtown with a handmade sign. On Friday, the movement kicked off in earnest with more than 50 individuals joining him.

The community has been mostly supportive, said Rebecca Shaw, an Ashland woman who attended demonstrations Saturday through Monday her 3-year-old and 5-year-old children and her girlfriend. A few passersby over the weekend yelled things like "all lives matter" and "Trump 2020," Shaw said.

Ashland City Police Officer Kara Pearce joined the demonstration on Sunday and held a "Black Lives Matter" sign. Pearce did not return a phone message or email seeking comment Monday.

"We are proud and thankful that our local community has chosen to demonstrate peacefully," said Ashland City Police Chief David Marcelli in an emailed statement.

"Members of the Division are free to participate in demonstrations or not participate as they choose," he said, noting, "I have received a number of positive comments concerning Pearce's appearance at the demonstration."

Mark Gorsuch, a Mapleton High School and Ashland University graduate, said on his first day protesting Monday that he plans to come back every day this week.

"Ashland is considered sometimes a backward town where civil rights aren't really emphasized, and I want to show that our community is one that values civil rights, too," he said.

According to the 2010 U.S. Census, less than 2% of the city of Ashland's approximately 20,000 residents and fewer than 1% of Ashland County's roughly 50,000 residents are black. When asked about the number of minority officers on city police staff, Marcelli said the department does not ask applicants about "race, creed, national origin, or religion."

"We currently have three female officers, the most at any time in our history," he noted.

Coming together

Protester Alexis Thomas acknowledged that racism exists in small towns like Ashland, where people "need to come together."

An Ashland native attending Kent State University, Thomas held a sign that read "racism is a pandemic too," when she attended demonstrations on Saturday and Monday. She said she wants to participate whenever she can.

While loud protests will continue, a group of local young adults is planning a vigil for victims of police brutality to be held at 7 p.m. Tuesday at Brookside West Park.

Hannah Caram, an Ashland native and University of Findlay student who is among the organizers, said the event is not a demonstration against any police officers or the Ashland City Police Department. The event's Facebook page notes, "we welcome any officers who wish to bow their heads with us."

"This event is to support black voices, and it is our responsibility to listen, learn, and use our privilege to lift up black communities, especially within Ashland," Caram said. The vigil will honor "the lives that we've lost and will shed light on them. People will say their names and be more educated about their stories."

At the vigil, Rev. Wilson Arimi will lead participants in prayer and Columbus-based political activist Latyna M. Humphrey will speak about unity. Attendees are encouraged to social distance, wear masks and bring water.
